title: The Tunnel Rat
text: The tunnel rat is not a real rat. It walks on two legs. It has a small knife in its hand. Its eyes are yellow. They shine in the dark. Tunnel rats live in old places under the ground. They eat old food and dead things. Sometimes they eat each other. One tunnel rat is not dangerous. But they never walk alone. When you see one, twenty more are watching you.

title: The Broken Lantern
text: This old lamp has a crack in its glass. It still works, but the fire inside is green, not orange. When you hold it up, you can see strange things. Old blood on the floor shines bright. You can see footprints in the dust. Sometimes you see a face in the corner of your eye. The lamp shows what happened here before. Not everyone wants to know.

title: The School Bell
text: Every morning is the same. The alarm rings at seven. The bed is warm. The floor is cold. Breakfast is too fast — always too fast. The bus comes at 7:42. If you miss it, you walk. If you walk, you are late. Today the bell rings when you get to school. Your heart beats fast. You run to the classroom. The door is still open. You sit down one second before the teacher turns around. Safe. Tomorrow you will wake up earlier. But the bed will still be warm.

title: A Warning About Mimics
text: If you are reading this, you are alive. Good. Now listen: not everything in this place is what it looks like. That box over there? It might be hungry. That wooden door? It might have teeth. We call them Mimics. They copy things and wait. When someone touches them, they attack. My advice: throw a stone at everything before you touch it. If it screams, don't open it. If it runs away, don't follow it. And if you see two doors that look the same next to each other — leave. Just leave. Trust me.

title: The Whispering Moss
text: The green moss on the walls is not normal. It whispers. At first, you think it is the wind. Then you see there is no wind down here. The moss repeats the last words of everyone who died in this corridor. Pieces of screams. Last prayers. Sometimes useful things: 'Trap ahead' or 'Don't trust the dwarf.' The longer you listen, the harder it is to stop. Some adventurers sit down next to the moss and never get up again. They just listen, forever, to voices that cannot help them anymore.

title: The Spartan Checkpoint
text: Two soldiers stand on the road. They wear red clothes and have long, sharp sticks. 'Stop!' says one soldier. He looks old and strong. 'You cannot go to Sparta. Where are you from? Why are you here?' He looks at your face. He looks at your bag. He looks at your clothes. 'Tell me the truth,' he says. 'Do not lie to us.' His eyes are cold. The other soldier says nothing. He just watches. You must answer now.

title: The Attention Thief
text: They call it 'brainrot content.' Short videos. Loud sounds. Bright colours. Always something new, every three seconds. Your brain loves it because it is easy. No thinking. Just watch, scroll, watch, scroll. But here is the problem: every video takes a little piece of your attention. After one hour of scrolling, try reading a book. It is hard. Your brain wants the next video. Scientists have studied this. The more brainrot you watch, the harder it is to concentrate. Your attention is like a muscle. If you only use it for three-second videos, it becomes weak.

title: The Bone Collector
text: Nobody knows what the Bone Collector was before it died. Now it is two metres of old cloth and clicking bones. It walks through dark places at night, collecting bones from the dead. It puts them carefully into bags: skulls in one bag, ribs in another, finger bones in a third. If you hide and stay quiet, it will walk past you. But if you have bones that don't belong to you — a lucky rabbit's foot, a necklace of teeth, a skull you took as a trophy — it will know. And it will want them back. It always gets what it wants.

title: Ambush in the Ruins
text: The arrow came from nowhere. It hit the stone wall behind your head with a loud crack. Two goblins dropped from the broken ceiling — small, green, and fast. A third stood in the doorway, already pulling another arrow from its bag. The ruins were supposed to be empty. The map said so. But goblins cannot read maps. They don't care what humans write on paper. They only care that you walked into their home. Now you have three seconds to decide: fight, run, or try to talk.

title: The Ring of the Fallen Knight
text: You found the ring on a skeleton's finger. The skeleton was wearing armour that was once beautiful. Now rust covers everything except the ring. It is silver, with a blue stone that still shines. When you put it on, you feel stronger. Braver. You hear a voice in your head: 'I am Sir Aldric. I died here forty years ago. My quest was never finished. Will you finish it for me?' The ring cannot come off now. Sir Aldric is very polite about it, but he is also very clear: you will complete his quest, or you will join him in death. Most people throw the ring away when they hear this. But you cannot throw away something that will not leave your finger.

title: Contract: Theron's Wolf
text: BOUNTY — 500 DRACHMAE. A wolf has been killing sheep near the village of Theron. This is no ordinary wolf. Hunters say it is bigger than a horse. Its fur is black as midnight. Its eyes glow red in the darkness. Three hunters have tried to kill it. None came back. The village elder believes the wolf is cursed — perhaps a man transformed by the gods as punishment. Kill the beast and bring its head to the elder. Warning: The wolf has been seen near the old temple of Artemis. The goddess protects all wild animals. If you make her angry, not even the walls of Athens will keep you safe.

title: The Group Project
text: The teacher said the words everyone hates: 'Get into groups of four.' Your friends grabbed each other before you could move. Now they have four people already. They give you a sorry look. You look around. Everyone is making groups. Everyone has friends. You see three other students standing alone, looking as lost as you feel. The teacher points at all of you: 'You four. Together.' You don't know these people. One looks angry. One looks scared. One is already on their phone. This is your team now. The project is due in two weeks. Maybe it will be fine. Maybe you will become friends. Or maybe you will do all the work while they play games.

title: The Drowned Temple
text: Day 3 in the temple. The water rises every night and goes down every morning. We found air pockets in the ceiling where we can breathe and sleep. The carvings on the walls tell the story of a sea god who was forgotten. His priests drowned themselves when the last believer died. Now their ghosts swim through these halls, still doing rituals that nobody watches. They ignore us mostly. But yesterday, Mira said she heard singing under the water. Beautiful singing. She wanted to dive down and find it. We had to tie her to a pillar. The singing hasn't stopped. I'm starting to understand the words.

title: Note from the Mad Wizard
text: Day 47 — The experiment continues. I have successfully merged the soul of a cat with the body of an owl. The result screams constantly. I consider this progress. Day 52 — The screaming has stopped. The cat-owl watches me now. It knows things it should not know. When I sleep, I dream of mice dying in moonlight. Day 61 — I understand now. I was wrong. The owl did not receive the cat's soul. The cat received mine. I am the experiment. I have always been the experiment. I am writing this with paws that used to be hands. title: The Thing That Ate My Sword
text: It looked almost cute at first. Like a big insect with feathery feelers and a long tail. It didn't attack us. It just walked toward Marcus, making happy clicking sounds. Then it touched his shield. The metal crumbled like old bread. The creature ate the rust that fell to the ground, making satisfied noises. Marcus drew his sword. The creature's feelers twitched with excitement. The sword dissolved where its feelers touched. We ran. I still have my leather armour. Marcus has his underclothes and his dignity. Actually, he lost the dignity too when he screamed. We don't talk about that. Lesson learned: Rust Monsters don't want to kill you. They just want to eat everything you own.

title: The Oracle of Delphi
text: The temple smelled of smoke and something else — something old. The Pythia sat on a three-legged stool above a crack in the earth. Strange fumes rose from below. Her eyes were completely white. 'You seek the Wolf of Sparta,' she said. Her voice was not her own. It was deeper, older, coming from somewhere far away. 'He hides where the lion's shadow falls at noon. But beware — the one you hunt also hunts you. Blood calls to blood. The eagle and the wolf share the same father.' She screamed suddenly, a terrible sound, and collapsed. The priests rushed to help her. When she woke, she remembered nothing. But you remember every word.

title: Margrath, the Hollow King
text: The throne room doors opened by themselves. On the ancient throne sat what was left of King Margrath the Fourth. His crown still sat on his skull. His royal robes hung on bones that had forgotten flesh three hundred years ago. But his eyes — two points of cold blue fire — those remembered everything. 'Another adventurer,' his voice echoed from nowhere and everywhere. 'They always come for the crown. They never leave with it.' The skeletal king stood. He was tall in life. In death, he was taller. His sword scraped against the stone floor as he descended the steps — a blade so old that rust had become part of its edge, yet sharp enough to cut through shadows. 'I have killed nine hundred and seventy-three heroes in this room,' Margrath said. 'You will be nine hundred and seventy-four. Unless...' He paused. 'Unless you can answer my riddle. I do so enjoy riddles.'

title: The Eye Tyrant
text: It was floating in the centre of the room, a nightmare that had become real. A ball of ugly skin, about one metre wide, with one very big eye in the middle. Around it, ten smaller eyes moved on stalks, each looking in a different direction. Each eye held a different death. 'You are either very brave or very stupid,' it said. Its voice was polite, almost friendly. 'I am Xanathar. Well, I call myself Xanathar. The first one died hundreds of years ago. But names have power, and his had enough power to keep me alive through seven killers, three groups of adventurers, and one very patient knight who never gave up.' Two of its eye stalks turned to look at you. 'I wonder which death you will get. The beam that makes you disappear is quick. The beam that turns you to stone lets me add you to my collection. So many choices, so many choices.'
